docs.title: Using AutoRecovery
docs.description: When a bookie crashes, all ledgers on that bookie become under-replicated. In order to bring all ledgers in your BookKeeper cluster back to full replication, you'll need to recover the data from any offline bookies. There are two ways to recover bookies' data:

docs.title: BookKeeper administration
docs.description: This document is a guide to deploying, administering, and maintaining BookKeeper. It also discusses best practices and common problems.

docs.description: This document introduces BookKeeper HTTP endpoints, which can be used for BookKeeper administration.

docs.title: Metric collection
docs.description: BookKeeper enables metrics collection through a variety of stats providers.

docs.description: If you have questions about upgrades (or need help), please feel free to reach out to us by mailing list or Slack Channel.

docs.title: DistributedLog
docs.description: DistributedLog began its life as a separate project under the Apache Foundation. It was merged into BookKeeper in 2017.

docs.title: The Advanced Ledger API
docs.description: In release 4.5.0, Apache BookKeeper introduces a few advanced API for advanced usage.

docs.description: The ledger API is a lower-level API for BookKeeper that enables you to interact with ledgers directly.

docs.description: BookKeeper offers a few APIs that applications can use to interact with it:

docs.title: Deploying BookKeeper on DC/OS
docs.description: DC/OS (the DataCenter Operating System) is a distributed operating system used for deploying and managing applications and systems on Apache Mesos. DC/OS is an open-source tool created and maintained by Mesosphere.

docs.title: Deploying Apache BookKeeper on Kubernetes
docs.description: Apache BookKeeper can be easily deployed in Kubernetes clusters. The managed clusters on Google Container Engine is the most convenient way.

docs.title: Manual deployment
docs.description: The easiest way to deploy BookKeeper is using schedulers like DC/OS, but you can also deploy BookKeeper clusters manually. A BookKeeper cluster consists of two main components:

docs.title: The BookKeeper protocol
docs.description: BookKeeper uses a special replication protocol for guaranteeing persistent storage of entries in an ensemble of bookies.

docs.title: BookKeeper concepts and architecture
docs.description: BookKeeper is a service that provides persistent storage of streams of log entries---aka records---in sequences called ledgers. BookKeeper replicates stored entries across multiple servers.

docs.title: BookKeeper installation
docs.description: You can install BookKeeper either by downloading a GZipped tarball package or cloning the BookKeeper repository.

docs.title: Run bookies locally
docs.description: Bookies are individual BookKeeper servers. You can run an ensemble of bookies locally on a single machine using the localbookie command of the bookkeeper CLI tool and specifying the number of bookies you'd like to include in the ensemble.

docs.title: BookKeeper CLI tool reference
docs.description: bookkeeper command

docs.title: BookKeeper configuration
docs.description: The table below lists parameters that you can set to configure bookies. All configuration takes place in the bk_server.conf file in the bookkeeper-server/conf directory of your BookKeeper installation.

docs.title: BookKeeper Security
docs.description: In the 4.5.0 release, the BookKeeper community added a number of features that can be used, together or separately, to secure a BookKeeper cluster.

docs.description: Bookies support client authentication via SASL. Currently we only support GSSAPI (Kerberos). We will start

docs.description: Apache BookKeeper allows clients and autorecovery daemons to communicate over TLS, although this is not enabled by default.

docs.description: The table below lists parameters that you can set to configure bookies. All configuration takes place in the bk_server.conf file in the bookkeeper-server/conf directory of your BookKeeper installation.

docs.title: BookKeeper Security
docs.description: In the 4.5.0 release, the BookKeeper community added a number of features that can be used, together or separately, to secure a BookKeeper cluster.

docs.title: Authentication using SASL
docs.description: Bookies support client authentication via SASL. Currently we only support GSSAPI (Kerberos). We will start

docs.title: Encryption and Authentication using TLS
docs.description: Apache BookKeeper allows clients and autorecovery daemons to communicate over TLS, although this is not enabled by default.

docs.description: New Clusters

docs.title: Using AutoRecovery
docs.description: When a bookie crashes, all ledgers on that bookie become under-replicated. In order to bring all ledgers in your BookKeeper cluster back to full replication, you'll need to recover the data from any offline bookies. There are two ways to recover bookies' data:

docs.title: BookKeeper administration
docs.description: This document is a guide to deploying, administering, and maintaining BookKeeper. It also discusses best practices and common problems.

docs.title: Geo-replication
docs.description: Geo-replication is the replication of data across BookKeeper clusters. In order to enable geo-replication for a group of BookKeeper clusters,

docs.title: BookKeeper Admin REST API
docs.description: This document introduces BookKeeper HTTP endpoints, which can be used for BookKeeper administration.

docs.title: Metric collection
docs.description: BookKeeper enables metrics collection through a variety of stats providers.

docs.title: Upgrade
docs.description: If you have questions about upgrades (or need help), please feel free to reach out to us by mailing list or Slack Channel.

docs.title: DistributedLog
docs.description: DistributedLog began its life as a separate project under the Apache Foundation. It was merged into BookKeeper in 2017.

docs.title: The Advanced Ledger API
docs.description: In release 4.5.0, Apache BookKeeper introduces a few advanced API for advanced usage.

docs.title: The Ledger API
docs.description: The ledger API is a lower-level API for BookKeeper that enables you to interact with ledgers directly.

docs.title: BookKeeper API
docs.description: BookKeeper offers a few APIs that applications can use to interact with it:

docs.title: Deploying BookKeeper on DC/OS
docs.description: DC/OS (the DataCenter Operating System) is a distributed operating system used for deploying and managing applications and systems on Apache Mesos. DC/OS is an open-source tool created and maintained by Mesosphere.

docs.title: Deploying Apache BookKeeper on Kubernetes
docs.description: Apache BookKeeper can be easily deployed in Kubernetes clusters. The managed clusters on Google Container Engine is the most convenient way.

docs.title: Manual deployment
docs.description: The easiest way to deploy BookKeeper is using schedulers like DC/OS, but you can also deploy BookKeeper clusters manually. A BookKeeper cluster consists of two main components:

docs.title: The BookKeeper protocol
docs.description: BookKeeper uses a special replication protocol for guaranteeing persistent storage of entries in an ensemble of bookies.

docs.title: BookKeeper concepts and architecture
docs.description: BookKeeper is a service that provides persistent storage of streams of log entries---aka records---in sequences called ledgers. BookKeeper replicates stored entries across multiple servers.

docs.title: BookKeeper installation
docs.description: You can install BookKeeper either by downloading a GZipped tarball package or cloning the BookKeeper repository.

docs.title: Run bookies locally
docs.description: Bookies are individual BookKeeper servers. You can run an ensemble of bookies locally on a single machine using the localbookie command of the bookkeeper CLI tool and specifying the number of bookies you'd like to include in the ensemble.

default.title: Apache BookKeeper Releases
default.description: Version {{ site.latest_release }} is the latest release of BookKeeper. The current stable version is {{ site.stable_release }}.

default.title: BP-20: github workflow for bookkeeper proposals
BP-21: New API close inconsistencies
default.description: Rejected due to lack of agreement that the issues raised in the motivation are valid.

default.title: BP-22: Separate closing ledgers from opening ledgers
default.description: Rejected due to lack of agreement that the issues raised in the motivation are valid.

default.title: BP-25: MovingChecksumToProto--Refactor the checksum part of bookkeeper
BP-26: Move distributedlog library as part of bookkeeper
BP-28: use etcd as metadata store
BP-33: Move releasing official docker images out of main repo
BP-37: Improve configuration management for better documentation
BP-38: Publish Bookie Service Info on Metadata Service
BP-41: Separate BookieId from Bookie Network Address
BP-42: New Client API - list ledgers
BookKeeper Proposals
default.description: This page describes a proposed BookKeeper Proposal (BP) process for proposing a major change to BookKeeper.

default.title: Coding guide
default.description: These guidelines are meant to encourage consistency and best practices among people working on Apache BookKeeper code base.

default.title: Contribution guide
default.description: The Apache BookKeeper community welcomes contributions from anyone with a passion for distributed systems! BookKeeper has many different opportunities for contributions --

default.title: Issue report
default.description: To report an issue, you will need to create a New Issue.

default.title: Third party dependencies and licensing
default.description: The bookkeeper project ships one source distribution and two binary distributions.

default.title: Mailing lists
default.description: Apache BookKeeper has several mailing lists that you can participate in.

default.title: Community meetings
default.description: The community meeting runs bi-weekly on Thursday 8am - 9am PST. The meeting link is https://goo.gl/iyRA6G.

default.title: Apache BookKeeper Release Guide
default.description: This page documents the procedure to make an Apache BookKeeper release.

default.title: Release Management
default.description: Apache BookKeeper community adopts Time Based Release Plan starting from 4.6.0.

default.title: Slack
default.description: There is an Apache BookKeeper channel that is used for informal discussions for BookKeeper developers and users.

default.title: Bylaws
default.description: This is version 1 of the bylaws. The BookKeeper PMC ratified these bylaws by a 2/3 majority vote on 2014/12/11.

default.title: Privacy policy
default.description: Information about your use of this website is collected using server access logs and a tracking cookie. The collected information consists of the following:
